content: Is it true that fderiv of a measurable function f : E → F is a measurable function uncurry (fderiv f) : E × E → F? I can prove this for the directional derivative dir_deriv f a v = deriv (λ t, f (a + t * v)) 0, so the question is whether the set {x | differentiable_at f x} is measurable. It is for E = \R. What about other domains?

Is this the same, or have I overlooked a hypothesis?
https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/905083/characterization-of-sets-of-differentiability
This answers "It is for E=RE = \mathbb RE=R"

It is true that the derivative of a function (measurable or not) is measurable when the target space is complete, as a map from EEE to the space of continuous linear maps from EEE to FFF. Let me give a proof.

Let me first show that the set of differentiability points is measurable. For r,s,ϵ>0r, s, \epsilon>0r,s,ϵ>0, let A(r,s,ϵ)A(r, s, \epsilon)A(r,s,ϵ) denote the set of points xxx for which there exist a continuous linear map LLL (a "candidate derivative") and two numbers r′∈(r/2,r)r' \in (r/2, r)r′∈(r/2,r) and s′∈(s/2,s)s'\in (s/2, s)s′∈(s/2,s) such that, for all y,z∈B(x,r′)y, z \in B(x,r')y,z∈B(x,r′), one has ∥f(z)−f(y)−L(z−y)∥≤ϵr\|f(z) - f(y) - L(z-y)\| \leq \epsilon r∥f(z)−f(y)−L(z−y)∥≤ϵr, and for all y,z∈B(x,s′)y, z \in B(x,s')y,z∈B(x,s′) one has ∥f(z)−f(y)−L(z−y)∥≤ϵs\|f(z)-f(y) - L (z-y)\| \leq \epsilon s∥f(z)−f(y)−L(z−y)∥≤ϵs.

It is clear that A(r,s,ϵ)A(r,s,\epsilon)A(r,s,ϵ) is open: indeed, if xxx belongs to this set, then any nearby point also does, upon reducing a little bit r′r'r′ and s′s's′ (and keeping the same LLL). I claim that the set of differentiability points is equal to D=⋂m⋃n⋂p,q≥nA(2−p,2−q,2−m)D = \bigcap_m \bigcup_n \bigcap_{p, q\ge n} A(2^{-p}, 2^{-q}, 2^{-m})D=⋂m​⋃n​⋂p,q≥n​A(2−p,2−q,2−m), from which the measurability follows readily.

We have two inclusions to show. Let us start with the easy one: if xxx is a point of differentiability, then it belongs to DDD. Fix some ϵ=2−m>0\epsilon = 2^{-m} > 0ϵ=2−m>0. Let LLL be the derivative of fff at xxx. For small enough rrr, one has for all y∈B(x,r)y\in B(x, r)y∈B(x,r) the inequality ∥f(y)−f(x)−L(y−x)∥≤(ϵ/2)∥y−x∥≤(ϵ/2)r\|f(y) - f(x) - L(y-x)\| \leq (\epsilon/2) \|y-x\| \leq (\epsilon/2) r∥f(y)−f(x)−L(y−x)∥≤(ϵ/2)∥y−x∥≤(ϵ/2)r. This shows that x∈A(ϵ,2−p,2−q)x \in A(\epsilon, 2^{-p},2^{-q})x∈A(ϵ,2−p,2−q) whenever ppp and qqq are large enough, as requested.

The other inclusion is a little bit harder. Take x∈Dx\in Dx∈D, we have to show that fff is differentiable at xxx. In particular, we should exhibit in some way its derivative. The main remark is that the candidate derivative is essentially unique: if two continuous linear maps LLL and L′L'L′ satisfy ∥f(z)−f(y)−L(z−y)∥≤ϵr\|f(z) -f(y) - L(z-y)\| \leq \epsilon r∥f(z)−f(y)−L(z−y)∥≤ϵr (and the same for L′L'L′) for all y,z∈B(x,r/2)y,z \in B(x,r/2)y,z∈B(x,r/2) for some r>0r>0r>0, then ∥L−L′∥≤4ϵ\|L-L'\| \leq 4 \epsilon∥L−L′∥≤4ϵ (take any hhh, and apply the previous inequalities to y=xy=xy=x and z=x+(r/2)(h/∥h∥)z= x + (r/2) (h/\|h\|)z=x+(r/2)(h/∥h∥)).

Let ϵ=2−m\epsilon=2^{-m}ϵ=2−m. The assumption that xxx belongs to DDD ensures that, for p,qp,qp,q larger than some n=n(m)n=n(m)n=n(m), then xxx belongs to A(2−p,2−q,ϵ)A(2^{-p}, 2^{-q}, \epsilon)A(2−p,2−q,ϵ), yielding a candidate derivative L(p,q,ϵ)L(p, q, \epsilon)L(p,q,ϵ). The almost uniqueness argument above shows that L(p,q,ϵ)L(p,q,\epsilon)L(p,q,ϵ) is within 4ϵ4\epsilon4ϵ of L(n,q,ϵ)L(n, q, \epsilon)L(n,q,ϵ) (using the fact that both these candidate derivatives work in a ball of radius roughly 2−q2^{-q}2−q), which is itself withing 4ϵ4\epsilon4ϵ of L(n,n,ϵ)L(n, n, \epsilon)L(n,n,ϵ) (same argument using the ball of radius 2−n2^{-n}2−n).

Let L(m)=L(n(m),n(m),2−m)L(m) = L(n(m), n(m), 2^{-m})L(m)=L(n(m),n(m),2−m). The same argument shows that L(m)L(m)L(m) and L(m′)L(m')L(m′) are within distance 20⋅2−m20 \cdot 2^{-m}20⋅2−m of each other when m′≥mm' \geq mm′≥m, as they are both candidate derivatives on a common ball of very small radius. It follows that L(m)L(m)L(m) is a Cauchy sequence, converging to a continuous linear operator LLL by completeness. It follows readily that LLL is a derivative of fff at xxx.

This concludes the proof of the measurability of the set of differentiability points. The measurability of the differential is proved similarly. One should show that, for any closed set BBB in the space of continuous linear maps from EEE to FFF, the set of points xxx where fff is differentiable with derivative in BBB is measurable. This set can be described exactly as before, requiring additionally in the definition of AAA that the candidate derivative LLL belongs to BBB.

Comparing the two proofs, I think I like mine better because it gives a lower complexity in the Borel scale for the differentiability set (it shows that the differentiability set is a countable intersection of union of intersection of open sets, while yours give something like intersection of union of intersection of union of something which is measurable, but not open).
